trial_identification.studytitle: Bacterial contamination of antibacterial contact lens cases during daily wear of marketed contact lenses
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Prospective, single-group, open label, bilateral daily wear study to investigate bacterial contamination of antibacterial contact lens cases when used in conjunction with marketed contact lenses in healthy volunteers
trial_identification.trialacronym: Antibacterial contact lens case contamination during daily wear

conditions.healthcondition: Bacterial contamination of antibacterial lens cases when used in conjunction with marketed contact lenses on a daily wear (ie. wearing contact lenses during the day and removing prior to sleep) schedule

interventions.interventions: All participants will be dispensed with commercially available Purevision (balafilcon A) lenses with antibacterial lens case. Participants will wear lenses on a daily wear (ie. not sleeping in the lenses) basis for 4 months. Lens performance will be assessed at the baseline visit, and after 2 weeks, 1 month, 3 months and 4 months. Lens cases will be collected for microbiological analysis at the monthly visits. All participants will use the same brand of lenses and antibacterial lens case
interventions.comparator: Historical control. The study to which we will be comparing this study used the same lens type, solution and similar visit schedule (up to the 3 month visit) as the current study, the only difference is the type of lens case used. In the historical control a regular lens case was used.

primaryOutcome.outcome: To assess bacterial contamination of antibacterial lens cases when used in conjunction with marketed contact lenses on a daily wear (ie. contact lenses worn during the day and removed prior to sleep) schedule. Used contact lens storage cases will be collected at the end of the clinical trial and transferred to the Institute for Eye Research (IER) microbiology laboratory. Swab samples will be taken from inner surfaces of lens cases for routine microbiology isolation and identification. Contamination rate of used cases will be then determined based on data from microbiological analysis
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At 1 month, 3 months and 4 months from the baseline visit

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Level 5, Rupert Myers Building Gate 14, Barker St University of New South Wales (UNSW), Kensington NSW 2052

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Level 5, Rupert Myers Building Gate 14, Barker St University of New South Wales (UNSW), Kensington NSW 2052

ethicsAndSummary.summary: hypotheses for this study include: Study hypothesis is that antibacterial lens cases will have less contamination inside the lens storage case than a regular lens case. Primary purpsoe of the study is to assess bacterial contamination of antibacterial contact lens cases when used in conjunction with marketed contact lenses worn on a daily wear and monthly replacement schedule and to compare the results to a historical control.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Vision Cooperative Research Ventre and Institute for Eye Research Human Ethics Committee
